revisions.rev:
{{Main|Ubuntu (operating system)}} [[File:Ubuntu 11.10 Final.png|thumb|Ubuntu 11.10 ''Oneiric Ocelot'', the latest stable release of Ubuntu.]] '''Ubuntu releases''' are made semiannually by [[Canonical Ltd]], the developers of the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] [[operating system]], using the year and month of the release as a [[Software versioning|version number]]. The first Ubuntu release, for example, was Ubuntu 4.10 and was released on 20 October 2004.<ref name="aboutUbuntu">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/project/about-ubuntu |title=About Ubuntu The Ubuntu story |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="wartyRelease" /> Consequently, version numbers for future versions are provisional; if the release is delayed until a different month to that planned, the version number changes accordingly.<ref name="timeBasedReleases">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TimeBasedReleases |title=TimeBasedReleases |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref>
Ubuntu releases are timed to be approximately one month after [[GNOME]] releases, which are in turn about one month after releases of [[X.Org]], resulting in each Ubuntu release including a newer version of GNOME and X.<ref name="ubuntuReleases">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Releases |title=Releases |accessdate=28 February 2010 |publisher=Canonical Ltd.}}</ref><ref name="gnomeTimeBasedReleases">{{cite web |url=http://live.gnome.org/ReleasePlanning/TimeBased |title=GNOME's Time-Based Release Schedule |work=Gnome Live Wiki |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="xTimeBasedReleases">{{cite mailing list |url=http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/xorg-devel/2009-September/002330.html |title=New release process |date=30 August 2009 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=xorg-devel |last=Stone |first=Daniel}}</ref>
To date every fourth release, in the second quarter of even-numbered years, has been designated as a Long Term Support (LTS) release, indicating that it has updates for three years for desktop use and five years for server, with paid technical support also available from [[Canonical Ltd.]] Releases 6.06, 8.04, and 10.04 are the LTS releases.<ref name="lts">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/LTS |title=LTS |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> Non-LTS releases have typically been supported for 18 months, and to date have always been supported until at least the date of the next LTS release. Therefore, users who have a non-LTS release can still safely set the Update Manager to notify about "LTS releases only" if they wish.
==Naming convention== Ubuntu releases are also given [[code name]]s, using an adjective and an animal with the same first letter (e.g. ''Dapper Drake''). With the exception of the first two releases, code names are in alphabetical order, allowing a quick determination of which release is newer. Commonly, Ubuntu releases are often referred to using only the adjective portion of the code name (e.g. ''Dapper'').<ref name="devCodeNames">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DevelopmentCodeNames |title=DevelopmentCodeNames |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=8 May 2009}}</ref>
==Release history== ===Ubuntu 4.10 (Warty Warthog)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-410-20080706.png|thumb|Ubuntu 4.10 (''Warty Warthog'')]] Ubuntu 4.10 (''Warty Warthog''), released on 20 October 2004, was Canonical's first release of Ubuntu, building upon [[Debian]], with plans for a new release every six months and eighteen months of support thereafter.<ref name="wartyRelease">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2004-October/000003.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 announcement |date=20 October 2004 |accessdate=19 August 2008 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |authorlink=Mark Shuttleworth}}</ref> Ubuntu 4.10's support ended on 30 April 2006.<ref name="wartySupport">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-March/000061.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 reaches end of life on 30 April 2006 |date=28 March 2006 |accessdate=19 August 2008 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Zimmerman |first=Matt}}</ref> Ubuntu 4.10 was the first version of Ubuntu to offer ShipIt services, allowing users to order free install CDs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/WartyWarthogFinalReleaseAnnouncement |title=WartyWarthogFinalReleaseAnnouncement |date=23 July 2005 |accessdate=5 March 2008}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 5.04 (Hoary Hedgehog)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-504-20080706.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 5.04 (''Hoary Hedgehog'')]] Ubuntu 5.04 (''Hoary Hedgehog''), released on 8 April 2005,<ref name="hoaryRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2005-April/000023.html |title=Ubuntu 5.04 announcement |date=8 April 2005 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Zimmerman |first=Matt}}</ref><ref name="hoaryRelease2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/504 |title=5.04 Release Notes |date=8 April 2005 |accessdate=19 August 2008 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080430232054/http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/504 |archivedate=30 April 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's second release of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 5.04's support ended on 31 October 2006.<ref name="hoarySupport">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-security-announce/2006-October/000418.html |title=Ubuntu 5.04 reaches end-of-life on 31 October 2006 |date=23 October 2006 |accessdate=19 August 2008 |mailinglist=ubuntu-security-announce |last=Armstrong |first=Christina}}</ref> Ubuntu 5.04 added many new features including an [[Update Manager|update manager]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/desktop/get-ubuntu/upgrade |title=Get Ubuntu: Upgrade |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> upgrade notifier, readahead and grepmap, suspend, [[hibernation (computing)|hibernate]] and [[Advanced Configuration and Power Interface|standby]] support, [[dynamic frequency scaling]] for processors, ubuntu hardware database, Kickstart installation, and [[Advanced Packaging Tool|APT]] authentication.<ref name="tuxRadar">{{cite web |url=http://www.tuxradar.com/content/road-jaunty-look-back-ubuntus-history |title=The road to Jaunty: a look back at Ubuntu's history |author=Tux Radar |date=23 April 2009 |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DraftHoaryReleaseAnnouncement |title=DraftHoaryReleaseAnnouncement |date=31 July 2005 |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=5 March 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 5.04 allowed installation from USB devices. Ubuntu 5.04 used [[UTF-8]] by default.
===Ubuntu 5.10 (Breezy Badger)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-510-20080706.png|thumb|Ubuntu 5.10 (''Breezy Badger'')]] Ubuntu 5.10 (''Breezy Badger''), released on 12 October 2005,<ref name="breezyRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2005-October/000038.html |title=Ubuntu 5.10 announcement |date=12 October 2005 |accessdate=19 August 2008 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Zimmerman |first=Matt}}</ref><ref name="breezyRelease2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/510 |title=Ubuntu 5.10 release notes |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=21 December 2006}}</ref> was Canonical's third release of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 5.10's support ended on 13 April 2007.<ref name="breezySupport">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-security-announce/2007-March/000504.html |title=Ubuntu 5.10 reaches end-of-life on 13 April 2007 |mailinglist=ubuntu-security-announce |last=Fog Heen |first=Tollef |date=14 March 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 5.10 added several new features including a graphical bootloader ([[Usplash]]), an Add/Remove Applications tool,<ref name="add/remove">{{cite web |url=https://help.ubuntu.com/7.04/add-applications/C/gnome-app-install.html |title=Add/Remove Applications |accessdate=11 October 2010 |work=Community Ubuntu Documentation |publisher=Canonical Ltd.}}</ref> a menu editor (alacarte), an easy language selector, [[logical volume management]] support, full [[Hewlett-Packard]] printer support, [[Original equipment manufacturer|OEM]] installer support, a new Ubuntu logo in the top-left, and [[Launchpad (website)|Launchpad]] integration for [[Software bug|bug]] reporting and software development.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/BreezyReleaseNotes |title=BreezyReleaseNotes |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |date=31 July 2005 |accessdate=5 March 2008}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 6.06 LTS (Dapper Drake)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-606-20080706.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 6.06 (''Dapper Drake'')]] Ubuntu 6.06 (''Dapper Drake''), released on 1 June 2006,<ref name="dapperRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-June/000083.html |title=Ubuntu 6.06 announcement |date=1 June 2006 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Zimmerman |first=Matt}}</ref><ref name="dapperRelease2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/606 |title=Ubuntu 6.06 LTS release notes |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref><ref name="dapperRelease3">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/606released |title=Ubuntu 6.06 LTS announcement |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's fourth release, and the first Long Term Support (LTS) release. Ubuntu 6.06 was released behind schedule, having been intended as 6.04. Development was not complete in April 2006 and [[Mark Shuttleworth]] approved slipping the release date to June, making it 6.06 instead.<ref name="FullCircleIssue0">{{cite web |url=http://fullcirclemagazine.org/download-manager.php?id=3 |title=FullCircle Magazine Issue 0 |accessdate=9 Juny 2009 |author=Full Circle Magazine |authorlink=Full Circle Magazine |date=April 2007}}</ref>
Ubuntu 6.06's support ended on 14 July 2009 for desktops and ended in June 2011 for servers.<ref name="breezySupportForDesktop">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2009-July/000123.html |title=Ubuntu 6.06 LTS Desktop Edition reaches end-of-life on 14 July 2009 |date=8 July 2009 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Langasek |first=Steve}}</ref> Ubuntu 6.06 included several new features, including having the [[Live CD]] and [[Installation (computer programs)|Install CD]] merged onto one disc,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.ubuntu.com/community/LiveCD |title=LiveCD |work=Community Ubuntu Documentation |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> a graphical installer on Live CD ([[Ubiquity (software)|Ubiquity]]), [[Usplash]] on shutdown as well as startup, a network manager for easy switching of multiple wired and wireless connections, Humanlooks theme implemented using [[Tango Desktop Project|Tango]] guidelines, based on [[Clearlooks]] and featuring orange colors instead of brown, and GDebi graphical installer for [[deb (file format)|package files]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?suite=default&section=all&arch=any&searchon=names&keywords=gdebi |title=Package gdebi |accessdate=11 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DapperDrake |title=DapperDrake |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |date=26 January 2007 |accessdate=5 March 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 6.06 did not include a means to install from a USB device, but did for the first time allow installation directly onto removable USB devices.
===Ubuntu 6.10 (Edgy Eft)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-610-20080708.png|thumb|Ubuntu 6.10 (''Edgy Eft'')]] Ubuntu 6.10 (''Edgy Eft''), released on 26 October 2006,<ref name="edgyRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-October/000093.html |title=Announcing Ubuntu 6.10 |date=26 October 2006 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Tollef Fog |first=Heen}}</ref><ref name="edgyRelease2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/610 |title=Ubuntu 6.10 release notes |accessdate=21 December 2006}}</ref><ref name="edgyRelease3">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/610released |title=Ubuntu 6.10 announcement |date=26 October 2006 |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's fifth release of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 6.10's support ended on 25 April 2008.<ref name="edgySupport1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-security-announce/2008-March/000680.html |title=Ubuntu 6.10 reaches end-of-life on 26 April 2008 |date=25 March 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-security-announce |last=Langasek |first=Steve}}</ref><ref name="edgySupport2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu610end-of-life |title=End of Life announcement for Ubuntu 6.10 |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |date=25 March 2008 |accessdate=1 April 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 6.10 added several new features including a heavily modified Human theme, [[Upstart]] [[init]] daemon, automated crash reports (Apport), [[Tomboy (software)|Tomboy]] note taking application, and [[F-Spot]] photo manager. EasyUbuntu, a third party program designed to make Ubuntu easier to use, was included in Ubuntu 6.10 as a meta-package.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/EdgyReleaseNotes |title=EdgyReleaseNotes |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |date=16 October 2007 |accessdate=5 March 2008}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 7.04 (Feisty Fawn)=== [[File:Ubuntu 7.04 Feisty Fawn.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 7.04 (''Feisty Fawn'')]] Ubuntu 7.04 (''Feisty Fawn''), released on 19 April 2007,<ref name="feistyRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2007-April/000102.html |title=Ubuntu 7.04 released |date=19 April 2007 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |author=Ubuntu Announcements}}</ref><ref name="feistyRelease2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/704 |title=Ubuntu 7.04 release notes |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="feistyRelease3">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/FeistyFawn |title=Ubuntu 7.04 announcement |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's sixth release of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 7.04's support ended on 19 October 2008.<ref name="feistySupport">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2008-September/000113.html |title=Ubuntu 7.04 reaches end-of-life on 19 October 2008 |date=26 August 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Langasek |first=Steve}}</ref> Ubuntu 7.04 included several new features, among them a migration assistant to help former [[Microsoft Windows]] users transition to Ubuntu, support for [[Kernel-based Virtual Machine]], assisted codec and restricted drivers installation including [[Adobe Flash]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[MP3]] support, easier installation of [[Nvidia]] and [[ATI Technologies|ATI]] drivers, [[Compiz]] desktop effects, support for [[Wi-Fi Protected Access]], the addition of [[Sudoku]] and [[chess]], a disk usage analyzer ([[baobab (software)|baobab]]), GNOME Control Center, and [[Zero configuration networking|Zeroconf]] support for many devices.<ref name="tuxRadar" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/feistybeta |title=feistybeta |date=23 March 2007 |accessdate=5 March 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 7.04 dropped support for [[PowerPC]] architecture.
===Ubuntu 7.10 (Gutsy Gibbon)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-710-20080708.png|thumb|Ubuntu 7.10 (''Gutsy Gibbon'')]] Ubuntu 7.10 (''Gutsy Gibbon''), released on 18 October 2007,<ref name="gutsyRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2007-October/000105.html |title=Ubuntu 7.10 released |date=18 October 2007 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |author=Ubuntu Announcements}}</ref><ref name="gutsyRelease2">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-devel-announce/2007-April/000276.html |title=Introducing the Gutsy Gibbon |date=12 April 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2008 |mailinglist=ubuntu-devel-announce |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark}}</ref><ref name="gutsyRelease3">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/GutsyReleaseSchedule |title=GutsyReleaseSchedule |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's seventh release of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 7.10's support ended on 18 April 2009.<ref name="gutsySupport1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2009-March/000118.html |title=Ubuntu 7.10 reaches end-of-life on 18 April 2009 |date=23 March 2009 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Langasek |first=Steve}}</ref><ref name="gutsySupport2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-7.10-eol |title=End of Life announcement for Ubuntu 7.10 |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 March 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 7.10 included several new features, among them [[AppArmor]] security framework,<ref name="tribe3">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe3 |title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 3 test release |accessdate=2 June 2008}}</ref> fast [[desktop search]],<ref name="tribe4">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe4 |title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 4 test release |accessdate=2 June 2008}}</ref> a Firefox plug-in manager (Ubufox),<ref name="tribe5">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe5 |title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 5 test release |accessdate=2 June 2008}}</ref> a graphical configuration tool for [[X.Org]], full [[NTFS]] support (read/write) via [[NTFS-3G]], and a revamped printing system with PDF printing by default.<ref name="tribe5" /> [[Compiz Fusion]] was enabled as default in Ubuntu 7.10<ref name="tribe2">{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe2 |title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 2 test release |accessdate=2 June 2008}}</ref> and [[Fast user switching]] was added.<ref name="tribe4" />
===Ubuntu 8.04 LTS (Hardy Heron)=== [[File:Ubuntu-desktop-2-804-20080708.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 8.04 (''Hardy Heron'')]] Ubuntu 8.04 (''Hardy Heron''), released on 24 April 2008,<ref name="hardyRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2008-April/000111.html |title=Ubuntu 8.04 LTS released |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |author=Ubuntu Announcements}}</ref><ref name="hardyRelease2">{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+milestone/ubuntu-8.04 |title=Milestone ubuntu-8.04 for Ubuntu due 24 April 2008 |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref><ref name="hardyRelease3">{{cite web |url=http://www.jonobacon.org/?p=1017 |title=Introducing the Hardy Heron |date=29 August 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's eighth release of Ubuntu and the second Long Term Support (LTS) release.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuWeeklyNewsletter/Issue36#head-1999d566299f6428162eb2f60acf5d12ad93f5d9 |title=Ubuntu Weekly Newsletter: Issue 36 |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=2 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-7344_3-6175365.html?hhTest=1&part=rss&tag=2547-1_3-0-5&subj=news |title=Ubuntu's new Linux sports debugging tool |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> Ubuntu 8.04's support ended on 12 May 2011 for desktops<ref name="HardyEOL">{{cite web|url = http://ubuntu-news.org/2011/04/11/ubuntu-8-04-reaches-end-of-life-on-may-12-2011/|title = Ubuntu 8.04 reaches end-of-life on May 12, 2011|accessdate = 15 May 2011|last = Handler|first = N.|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = April}}</ref> and will end in April 2013 for servers. Ubuntu 8.04 included several new features, among them [[MetaTracker (software)|Tracker]] desktop search integration,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20071101-ubuntu-developer-summit-lays-out-vision-for-strong-hardy-heron-release.html |title=Ubuntu developer summit Boston |date=1 November 2007 |accessdate=2 June 2008}}</ref> [[Brasero (software)|Brasero]] disk burner,<ref name="BrasTransVin" /> [[Transmission (BitTorrent client)|Transmission]] [[Comparison of BitTorrent clients|BitTorrent client]],<ref name="BrasTransVin" /> [[Vinagre]] [[Virtual Network Computing|VNC]] client,<ref name="BrasTransVin">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/hardy-changes/2008-January/004677.html |title=Accepted: ubuntu-meta 1.87 (source) |date=14 January 2008 |accessdate=21 January 2008 |mailinglist=hardy-changes |last=Pitt |first=Martin}}</ref> system sound through [[PulseAudio]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+spec/cleanup-audio-jumble |title=Blueprint: "Fix the Linux audio mess once and for all" |accessdate=19 July 2008}}</ref> and [[Active Directory]] authentication and login using Likewise Open.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-8.04-lts-server |title=Latest Server Release Expands Ubuntu Enterprise Profile |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=5 July 2008}}</ref> In addition Ubuntu 8.04 included updates for better [[Tango Desktop Project|Tango]] compliance,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Artwork/Incoming/Hardy |title=Hardy Heron Artwork |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> various Compiz usability improvements, automatic grabbing and releasing of the mouse cursor when running on a [[VMware]] virtual machine, and an easier method to remove Ubuntu. Ubuntu 8.04 was the first version of Ubuntu to include the [[Wubi (Ubuntu installer)|Wubi]] installer on the Live CD that allows Ubuntu to be installed as a single file on a Windows hard drive without the need to repartition the disk.
===Ubuntu 8.10 (Intrepid Ibex)=== [[File:Ubuntu screenshot.png|thumb|Ubuntu 8.10 (''Intrepid Ibex''). The default wallpaper depicts an [[Ibex]], with its large curved horns.]] Ubuntu 8.10 (''Intrepid Ibex''), released on 30 October 2008,<ref name="intrepidRelease1">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2008-October/000116.html |title=Ubuntu 8.10 released |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |author=Ubuntu Announcements}}</ref><ref name="intrepidRelease2">{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+milestone/ubuntu-8.10|title=Milestone ubuntu-8.10 for Ubuntu due 30 October 2008 |accessdate=28 April 2008}}</ref> was Canonical's ninth release of Ubuntu. Support ended on 30 April 2010.<ref name="intrepidSupport">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-security-announce/2010-March/001067.html |title=Ubuntu 8.10 reaches end-of-life on 30 April 2010 |date=29 March 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |mailinglist=ubuntu-security-announce |last=Langasek |first=Steve}}</ref> Ubuntu 8.10 introduced several new features including improvements to mobile computing and desktop scalability, increased flexibility for Internet connectivity, an [[Ubuntu Live USB creator]] and a guest account,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DesktopTeam/Specs/Intrepid/GuestAccount |title=Guest account specification |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=19 August 2008}}</ref> which allowed others to use a computer allowing very limited user rights (e.g. accessing the Internet, using software and checking e-mail).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lifehacker.com/5072351/a-users-look-at-ubuntu-810-intrepid-ibex |title=A User's Look at Ubuntu 8.10 Intrepid Ibex |last=Thomas |first=Keir |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> The guest account had its own home folder and nothing done on it was stored permanently on the computer's hard disk.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mopedia.co.uk/2008/09/ubuntu-intrepid-ibex-features.html |title=Ubuntu Intrepid Ibex Features |publisher=MoPedia |date=5 September 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> Intrepid Ibex also included an encrypted private directory for users,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/EncryptedPrivateDirectory |title=EncryptedPrivateDirectory |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> the inclusion of [[Dynamic Kernel Module Support]], a tool that allows kernel drivers to be automatically rebuilt when new kernels are released and support for creating [[USB flash drive]] images.<ref name="tuxRadar" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/IntrepidIbex/TechnicalOverview |title=IntrepidIbex/TechnicalOverview |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 9.04 (Jaunty Jackalope)=== [[File:Ubuntu 9.04 Jaunty Jackalope.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 9.04 (''Jaunty Jackalope'')]] Ubuntu 9.04 (''Jaunty Jackalope''), released on 23 April 2009,<ref name="jauntyReleased">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2009-April/000122.html |title=Ubuntu 9.04 released |author=Ubuntu Announcements |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |date=23 April 2009 |accessdate=23 April 2009}}</ref> was Canonical's tenth release of Ubuntu. Support ended on 23 October 2010.<ref name="jauntySupport">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2010-September/000137.html |title=Ubuntu 9.04 reaches end-of-life on 23 October 2010 |author=Robbie Williamson |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |date=23 September 2009 |accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref> New features included faster [[booting|boot]] time,<ref name="zdnet">{{cite web |url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/hardware/first-look-ubuntu-904-jaunty-jackalope-release-candidate/4181 |title=First look: Ubuntu 9.04 "Jaunty Jackalope" Release Candidate | Hardware 2.0 | ZDNet.com |publisher=Blogs.zdnet.com |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> integration of web services and applications into the desktop interface. It had a new [[usplash]] screen, a new [[Login|login screen]] and also support for both [[Wacom]] ([[Hot swapping|hotplugging]]) and [[netbook]]s.<ref name="zdnet" /> It also included a new notification system, ''Notify OSD'',<ref name="NotifyOSD">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/NotifyOSD |title=NotifyOSD |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=30 April 2009}}</ref> and [[Theme (computing)|themes]]. It marked the first time that all of Ubuntu's core development moved to the [[Bazaar (software)|Bazaar]] [[distributed revision control]] system.<ref name="ubuntu9.04Ann">{{cite mailing list |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-devel-announce/2008-September/000481.html |date=28 September 2008 |mailinglist=ubuntu-devel-announce |title=Introducing the Jaunty Jackalope |accessdate=9 September 2008}}</ref><ref name="jauntyReleaseSchedule">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/JauntyReleaseSchedule |title=JauntyReleaseSchedule |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=3 March 2009}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 9.10 (Karmic Koala)=== [[File:Ubuntu 9.10.png|thumb|Ubuntu 9.10 (''Karmic Koala'')]] Ubuntu 9.10 (''Karmic Koala''), released on 29 October 2009,<ref name="karmicReleased">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2009-October/000127.html |title=Ubuntu 9.10 released |author=Ubuntu Announcements |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |date=29 October 2009 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> was Canonical's 11th release of Ubuntu. It was supported until April 2011.<ref name="KarmicReleaseSchedule">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/KarmicReleaseSchedule |title=KarmicReleaseSchedule |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=3 March 2009}}</ref><ref name="Ubuntu 9.10 reaches end-of-life">{{cite web|title=Ubuntu reaches end-of-life on April 30, 2011|url=http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1716760|accessdate=30 April 2011}}</ref>
In an announcement to the community on 20 February 2009, Mark Shuttleworth explained that 9.10 would focus on improvements in [[cloud computing]] on the server using [[Eucalyptus (computing)|Eucalyptus]], further improvements in boot speed as well as development on the [[Ubuntu Netbook Edition|Netbook Remix]].<ref name="koala20Feb09">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-devel-announce/2009-February/000536.html |title=Introducing the Karmic Koala, our mascot for Ubuntu 9.10 |accessdate=21 February 2009 |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |mailinglist=ubuntu-devel-announce |date=February 2009}}</ref>
The initial announcement of version 9.10 indicated that this release might include a new theme, however the project was moved forward to 10.04,<ref name="koala20Feb09" /><ref name="softpedia12Jun09">{{cite web |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Ubuntu-9-10-Alpha-1-Released-113881.shtml |title=Ubuntu 9.10 Alpha 2 Released - The Karmic Koala Chronicles |accessdate=22 June 2009 |last=Nestor |first=Marius |date=June 2009}}</ref> and only minor revisions were made to the default theme. Other graphical improvements included a new set of boot up and shutdown splash screens, a new login screen that transitions seamlessly into the desktop and greatly improved performance on Intel graphics chipsets.
In June 2009 Canonical created the [[Paper cut (Ubuntu)|One Hundred Paper Cuts]] project, focusing developers to fix minor usability issues. A paper cut is defined as: ''"a trivially fixable usability bug that the average user would encounter on his/her first day of using a brand new installation of the latest version of Ubuntu Desktop Edition."''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/hundredpapercuts |title=One Hundred Paper Cuts |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref>
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 9.10 replaced [[Pidgin (software)|Pidgin]] with [[Empathy (software)|Empathy Instant Messenger]] as its default instant messaging client.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/karmic/i386/empathy |title="empathy" binary package in Ubuntu Karmic i386 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> The default filesystem is [[ext4]], and the [[Ubuntu One]] client, which interfaces with Canonical's new online storage system, is installed by default.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/karmic/alpha3 |title=Karmic Koala Alpha 3 |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |date=29 October 2009 |accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> It also debuted a new application called the [[Ubuntu Software Center]] that unifies package management. Canonical stated their intention for this application to replace Add/Remove Programs (gnome-app-install) in 9.10 and possibly Synaptic, Software Sources, Gdebi and Update Manager in Ubuntu 10.04.<ref name="phoronix27Aug09">{{cite web |url=http://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=article&item=ubuntu_software_store&num=1 |title=Canonical Unveils The Ubuntu Software Store |accessdate=15 August 2009 |last=Larabel |first=Michael |date=August 2009}}</ref> Karmic Koala also includes a slideshow during the installation process (through ubiquity-slideshow) that highlights applications and features in Ubuntu.
===Ubuntu 10.04 LTS (Lucid Lynx)=== [[File:Ubuntu 10.04 screenshot.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 10.04 (''Lucid Lynx'')]] Shuttleworth first announced Ubuntu 10.04 (''Lucid Lynx'')<ref name="devCodeNames" /> on 19 September 2009 at the Atlanta Linux Fest; Canonical released it on 29 April 2010.<ref name="lucidReleased">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2010-April/000133.html |title=Ubuntu 10.04 LTS released |author=Ubuntu Announcements |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |date=29 April 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="Paul23Sep09">{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2009/09/ubuntu-1004-lts-announced-codenamed-lucid-lynx.ars |title=Ubuntu 10.04 LTS announced, codenamed Lucid Lynx |accessdate=24 October 2009 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |date=September 2009}}</ref> It is Canonical's 12th release of Ubuntu and the third LTS release. Canonical intends to provide support for Ubuntu 10.04 until April 2013 for the desktop version, and until April 2015 for the server version. The same dates apply to [[Kubuntu]] 10.04, which is built on [[KDE]].
The new release includes, among other things, improved support for [[Nvidia]] proprietary graphics drivers, while switching to the open source Nvidia graphics driver, [[Nouveau (graphics)|Nouveau]], by default. [[Plymouth (software)|Plymouth]] was also introduced allowing boot animations.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bugs.edge.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/xserver-xorg-video-nv/+bug/454821/comments/2 |title=Bug #454821 : Bugs : "xserver-xorg-video-nv" package : Ubuntu |accessdate=24 February 2010 |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |year=2010}} </ref><ref name="LucidAlpha2"> {{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/lucid/alpha2 |title=Lucid Alpha 2 |accessdate=23 February 2010 |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |year=2010}} </ref><ref name="Plymouth"> {{cite web |url=https://edge.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/plymouth/+publishinghistory |title=Publishing history of "plymouth" package in Ubuntu |accessdate=29 June 2010 |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |date=June 2010}}</ref>
[[GIMP]] was removed from the Lucid installation CD due to its professional-grade complexity and its file size. [[F-Spot]] provides normal user-level graphics-editing capabilities and GIMP remains available for download in the repositories.<ref name="Paul24Nov09">{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2009/11/giving-up-the-gimp-is-a-sign-of-ubuntus-mainstream-maturity.ars |title=Giving up the GIMP is a sign of Ubuntu's mainstream maturity |accessdate=1 May 2010 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |date=November 2009}}</ref>
The distribution emphasizes the new importance of web services and [[social networking]] with integrated interfaces for posting to sites like [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]], complementing the IM and email integration already in Ubuntu.
On 4 March 2010, it was announced that Lucid Lynx would feature a new theme, including new logos, taking Ubuntu's new visual style<ref name="UbuntuWikiLightware">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Brand#Light:%20Ubuntu%20is%20Lightware |title=Light: Ubuntu is Lightware |publisher=ubuntu.com |accessdate=4 March 2010}}</ref> into account:
{{Quote |The new style in Ubuntu is inspired by the idea of "Light".
We're drawn to Light because it denotes both warmth and clarity, and intrigued by the idea that "light" is a good value in software. Good software is "light" in the sense that it uses your resources efficiently, runs quickly, and can easily be reshaped as needed. Ubuntu represents a break with the bloatware of proprietary operating systems and an opportunity to delight to those who use computers for work and play. More and more of our communications are powered by light, and in future, our processing power will depend on our ability to work with light, too.
Visually, light is beautiful, light is ethereal, light brings clarity and comfort.
Historical perspective: From 2004â2010, the theme in Ubuntu was "Human". Our tagline was "Linux for Human Beings" and we used a palette reflective of the full range of humanity. Our focus as a project was bringing Linux from the data center into the lives of our friends and global family. }}
Critical responses to the new theme have been mixed. [[Ars Technica]]'s Ryan Paul said "The new themes and updated color palette are nice improvement for Ubuntu... After testing the new theme for several hours, I feel like it's a step forward, but it still falls a bit short of my expectations." Paul also noted that the most controversial aspect of the new design amongst users has been the placement of the window control buttons on the left instead of the right side of the windows.<ref name="Paul06Mar10">{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/reviews/2010/03/hands-on-a-close-look-at-ubuntus-new-non-brown-theme.ars |title=Hands-on: a close look at Ubuntu's new non-brown theme |accessdate=8 March 2010 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |date=March 2010}} </ref><ref name="Paul04Mar10"> {{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/03/ubuntu-dumps-the-brown-introduces-new-theme.ars |title=Ubuntu dumps the brown, introduces new theme and branding |accessdate=8 March 2010 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |date=March 2010}}</ref> TechSource's Jun Auza expressed concern that the new theme is too close to that used by [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] [[Mac OS X]]: "I think Ubuntu is having an identity crisis right now and should seriously consider changing several things in terms of look and feel to avoid being branded as a Mac OS X rip-off, or worse, get sued by Apple." Auza also summarized Ubuntu user feedback: "I believe the fans are divided right now. Some have learned to love the brown color scheme since it uniquely represents Ubuntu, while others wanted change."<ref name="Auza04Mar10">{{cite web |url=http://www.junauza.com/2010/03/ubuntus-new-look-pale-imitation-of-mac.html |title=Ubuntu's New Look, a Pale Imitation of Mac OS X? |accessdate=8 March 2010 |last=Auza |first=Jun |date=March 2010}}</ref>
The first [[point release]] 10.04.1 was made available on 17 August 2010,<ref>{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2010-August/000134.html |title=Ubuntu 10.04.1 LTS released |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Williamson |first=Robbie |date=18 August 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref> the second update 10.04.2 was released on 17 February 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2011-February/000141.html |title=Ubuntu 10.04.2 LTS released |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref> and the third update 10.04.3 was released on 21 July 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ubuntu-news.org/2011/07/21/ubuntu-10-04-3-lucid-lynx-lts-released/ |title=Ubuntu 10.04.3 (Lucid Lynx) LTS released! |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref> The 10.04.4 update is scheduled for 25 January 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/LucidReleaseSchedule|title=LucidReleaseSchedule|accessdate=1 August 2011}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 10.10 (Maverick Meerkat)=== [[File:UbuntuMaverickDesktop.png|thumb|Ubuntu 10.10 (''Maverick [[Meerkat]]'')]] The naming of Ubuntu 10.10 (''Maverick Meerkat'') was announced by Mark Shuttleworth on 2 April 2010, along with the release's goals of improving the netbook experience and a server focus on hybrid cloud computing. Ubuntu 10.10 was released on 10 October 2010 (10.10.10) at around 10:10 UTC.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/336 |title=Shooting for the Perfect 10.10 with Maverick Meerkat |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="Paul02Apr10">{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/04/ubuntu-1010-to-be-codenamed-maverick-meerkat.ars |title=Ubuntu 10.10 to be codenamed Maverick Meerkat |accessdate=2 April 2010 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |date=April 2010}}</ref><ref name="MaverickReleaseSchedule">{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/MaverickReleaseSchedule |title=MaverickReleaseSchedule |work=Ubuntu Team Wiki |publisher=Canonical Ltd. |accessdate=6 April 2010 |date=April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2010-October/000139.html |title=Ubuntu 10.10 Release Announcement |author=Robbie Williamson |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neowin.net/news/ubuntu-1010-maverick-meerkat-released |title=Article on Ubuntu 10.10 Rlease |work=Andrew Lyle |accessdate=18 October 2010}}</ref> This is a departure from the traditional schedule of releasing at the end of October to get "the perfect 10",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/336 |title=Shooting for the Perfect 10.10 with Maverick Meerkat |publisher=Mark Shuttleworth |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=8 June 2010}}</ref> and a playful reference to ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'', since, in [[Binary numeral system|binary]], 101010 is equal to [[Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe and Everything|the number 42]], the "Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe and Everything" within the series.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-marketing/2010-May/003987.html |title=ubuntu-marketing: 10.10.10 |author=Mark Shuttleworth |date=11 May 2010 |work=lists.ubuntu.com |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> It is Canonical's 13th release of Ubuntu. New features included the new [[Unity (desktop environment)|Unity]] interface for the Netbook Edition, a new default photo manager, [[Shotwell (software)|Shotwell]], replacing [[F-Spot]], the ability to purchase applications in the Software Center, and an official [[Ubuntu Font Family|Ubuntu font]] used by default.<ref name="Paul10Oct10">{{Cite news |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/10/ubuntu-1010-arrives-with-impressive-new-netbook-environment.ars |title=Ubuntu 10.10 arrives with impressive new netbook environment |accessdate=15 October 2010 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |year=2010 |month=October |work=Ars Technica}}</ref> Maverick Meerkat 10.10 will be supported until April 2012.
===Ubuntu 11.04 (Natty Narwhal)=== [[File:Ubuntu 11.04.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 11.04 Desktop (''Natty Narwhal'') using [[Unity (desktop environment)|Unity.]]]] The naming of Ubuntu 11.04 (''Natty Narwhal'') was announced on 17 August 2010 by Mark Shuttleworth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/478 |title=N-imal? |author=Mark Shuttleworth |date=17 August 2010 |accessdate=17 August 2010}}</ref> Ubuntu 11.04 Natty Narwhal was released on 28 April 2011.<ref>{{cite news|last=Paul|first=Ryan|title=Ubuntu 11.04 released, a Natty Narwhal rises from the depths|url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2011/04/ubuntu-1104-released-a-natty-narwhal-rises-from-the-depths.ars|accessdate=29 April 2011|newspaper=Ars Technica|date=28 April 2011}}</ref> It is Canonical's 14th release of Ubuntu.
Ubuntu 11.04 used the [[Unity (desktop environment)|Unity]] user interface instead of [[GNOME Shell]] as default. The move to Unity was controversial as some [[GNOME]] developers feared it would fracture the community and marginalize GNOME Shell.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/17224/ubuntu_changes_its_desktop_from_gnome_to_unity |title=Ubuntu changes its desktop from GNOME to Unity |author=Mark Shuttleworth |date=25 October 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref><ref name="Paul26Oct10">{{Cite news |url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/10/shuttleworth-unity-shell-will-be-default-desktop-in-ubuntu-1104.ars |title=Shuttleworth: Unity shell will be default desktop in Ubuntu 11.04 |accessdate=26 October 2010 |last=Paul |first=Ryan |year=2010 |month=October |work=Ars Technica}}</ref> The [[GNOME]] desktop environment is still available in Ubuntu 11.04 under the title Ubuntu Classic as a fallback to [[Unity (desktop environment)|Unity]].
Ubuntu 11.04 employed [[Banshee (media player)|Banshee]] as the default music player, replacing [[Rhythmbox]]. Other new applications included [[Mozilla Firefox 4]] and [[LibreOffice]], which replaced [[OpenOffice.org]].<ref name="LibreOfficePubHist">{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/libreoffice/+publishinghistory |title=Publishing history of "libreoffice" package in Ubuntu |accessdate=20 January 2011 |last=[[Canonical Ltd]] |year=2011 |month=January}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-devel/2011-January/032298.html |title=LibreOffice for natty, replacing the current OpenOffice packaging |publisher=Lists.ubuntu.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/NattyNarwhal/TechnicalOverview#Ubuntu |title=Default Applications Listing for 11.04 |publisher=Wiki.ubuntu.com |date=2011-06-26 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> The [[OpenStack]] cloud computing platform was added in this release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/open-source/canonical-switches-to-openstack-for-ubuntu-linux-cloud/8875 |title=Canonical switches to OpenStack for Ubuntu Linux cloud |publisher=Zdnet.com |date=2011-05-10 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Prickett |first=Timothy |url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/05/10/canonical_ubuntu_openstack/ |title=Ubuntu eats OpenStack for clouds |publisher=Theregister.co.uk |date=2011-05-10 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref>
Starting with Ubuntu 11.04, the [[Ubuntu Netbook Edition]] was merged into the desktop edition.<ref name="Ubuntu1104alpha1">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/natty/alpha1 |title=Natty Narwhal Alpha 1 |accessdate=3 December 2010 |last=Canonical Ltd |year=2010 |month= December}}</ref>
In reviewing Ubuntu 11.04 upon its stable release, Ryan Paul of [[Ars Technica]] said "There is a lot to like in Ubuntu 11.04, but also a lot of room for improvement." Jesse Smith of [[Distrowatch]] said "I'm of the opinion there are good features in this release, but 11.04 definitely suffered from being rushed out the door while it was still beta quality. Ubuntu aims to be novice-friendly, but this release is buggy and I think they missed the mark this time around. I'm limiting my recommendation of 11.04 to people who want to play with an early release of Unity."<ref name="Paul29Apr11">{{Cite news|url = http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2011/04/ubuntu-1104-released-a-natty-narwhal-rises-from-the-depths.ars|title = Ubuntu 11.04 released, a Natty Narwhal rises from the depths|accessdate = 30 April 2011|last = Paul|first = Ryan|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = April| work =[[Ars Technica]]}}</ref><ref name="DW09May11">{{Cite news|url = http://distrowatch.com/weekly.php?issue=20110509#feature|title = A look at Ubuntu 11.04|accessdate = 10 May 2011|last = Smith|first = Jesse|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = May| work = [[Distrowatch]]}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 11.10 (Oneiric Ocelot)=== [[File:Ubuntu 11.10 Final.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 11.10 final release (October 13, 2011) running [[Unity (user interface)|Unity]] 4.22.0]] The naming of Ubuntu 11.10 (''Oneiric Ocelot'') was announced on 7 March 2011 by Mark Shuttleworth. He explained that Oneiric means "dreamy". <ref name="Shuttleworth07Mar11"> {{cite web|url = http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/646|title = Next after Natty?|accessdate = 9 September 2011|last = Shuttleworth|first = Mark|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = March}}</ref> Ubuntu 11.10 was released on schedule on 13 October 2011 and is Canonical's 15th release of Ubuntu.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/OneiricReleaseSchedule |title=OneiricReleaseSchedule - Ubuntu Wiki |publisher=Wiki.ubuntu.com |date=2011-10-07 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref>
In April 2011 Shuttleworth announced that Ubuntu 11.10 would not include the classic [[GNOME]] desktop as a fall back to [[Unity (desktop environment)|Unity]], unlike Ubuntu 11.04 Natty Narwhal. Instead, 11.10 will include a 2D version of Unity as a fallback for computers that lack the hardware resources for the [[Compiz]]-based 3D version. However, the classic GNOME desktop remains available as a fallback in Ubuntu 11.10 through a package in the Ubuntu repositories.<ref>http://www.webupd8.org/2011/08/installing-using-classic-gnome-desktop.html</ref> Shuttleworth also confirmed that Unity in Ubuntu 11.10 will run as a shell for GNOME 3 on top of GNOME 3 libraries, unlike in Ubuntu 11.04 where it ran as a shell for GNOME 2. Moreover, users will also be able to install the entire GNOME 3 stack along with [[GNOME Shell]] directly from the Ubuntu repositories, to be presented with a "GNOME 3 desktop" choice at login.<ref name="Shuttleworth07Apr11">{{cite web|url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/669|title=Celebrating Gnome 3.0|author=Mark Shuttleworth}}</ref> During the development cycle, there also have been many changes to Unity, including the placement of the Ubuntu button on the Launcher instead of on the Panel, the autohiding of the window controls (and the global menu) of maximized windows, the introduction of more [[Alpha compositing|transparency]] into the Dash (and the Panel if the Dash is opened), and the introduction of window controls for the Dash.<ref>{{cite web|author=« » |url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/717 |title=>> Blog >> Dash takes shape for 11.10 Unity |publisher=Mark Shuttleworth |date=2011-08-16 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref>
In May 2011 it was announced that [[PiTiVi]] would be no longer part of the Ubuntu ISO, starting with Ubuntu 11.10 Oneiric Ocelot. The reasons given for removing it included poor user reception, lack of fit with the default user-case for Ubuntu, lack of polish and the application's lack of development maturity. PiTiVi will not be replaced on the ISO with another video editor. Other changes include removing Computer Janitor, as it caused broken systems for users, and the removal of the [[Synaptic (software)|Synaptic]] package manager, which can optionally be installed via the [[Ubuntu Software Center]]. [[Duplicity (software)|DÃ©jÃ Dup]] has been added as Ubuntu's backup program.<ref name="Webupd8">{{cite web|url = http://www.webupd8.org/2011/06/synaptic-removed-from-ubuntu-1110-deja.html|title = synaptic removed from ubuntu 11.10|accessdate = 2011-06-23|last = |authorlink = |year = 2011|month = June}}</ref> [[Mozilla Thunderbird]] has replaced the [[Evolution (software)|Evolution]] email client. All removed applications will remain available to users for installation from the [[Ubuntu Software Center]] and [[Repositories]].<ref name="OMG13May11A">{{Cite news|url = http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/05/pitivi-to-be-removed-as-default-app-in-ubuntu-11-10/|title = Video editor PiTiVi to be removed as default app in Ubuntu 11.10|accessdate = 14 May 2011|last = Sneddon|first = Joey|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = May| work = OMG Ubuntu}}</ref><ref name="OMG13May11B">{{Cite news|url = http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/05/app-changes-for-ubuntu-11-10-so-long-computer-janitor-hello-deja-dup/|title = App changes for Ubuntu 11.10: See ya, Computer Janitor and Hello Deja Dup!|accessdate = 14 May 2011|last = Sneddon|first = Joey|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = May| work = OMG Ubuntu}}</ref><ref name="OMG12May11">{{Cite news|url = http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/05/no-concrete-decision-taken-on-default-ubuntu-mail-app-for-11-10-but-errs-towards-thunderbird/|title = Thunderbird on track to be default e-mail app in Ubuntu 11.10|accessdate = 14 May 2011|last = Sneddon|first = Joey|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = May| work = [[OMG Ubuntu]]}}</ref><ref name="OMG10Aug11">{{Cite news|url = http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/08/thunderbird-confirmed-default-mail-app-ubuntu-11-10/|title = Thunderbird Confirmed as Default Mail App For Ubuntu 11.10|accessdate = 10 August 2011|last = Sneddon|first = Joey|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = August| work = [[OMG Ubuntu]]}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 12.04 LTS (Precise Pangolin)=== Ubuntu 12.04 LTS (''Precise Pangolin'') will be the next release after 11.10 and will be a Long Term Support (LTS) release.<ref name="ocelot_announce">{{cite web|url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/646|title=Next after Natty?|author=Mark Shuttleworth}}</ref> The name for the release was announced by Shuttleworth on 5 October 2011.<ref name="Shuttleworth05Oct11"> {{cite web|url = http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/784 |title = P is forâ¦|accessdate = 5 October 2011|last = Shuttleworth|first = Mark|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = October}}</ref> Unlike previous LTS releases that have been supported for three years for the desktop version and five years for the server version, this release will be supported for five years on both.<ref name="Canonical5yearLTS">{{cite web|url=http://www.canonical.com/content/ubuntu-1204-feature-extended-support-period-desktop-users |title=Ubuntu 12.04 to feature extended support period for desktop users |publisher=Canonical.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref><ref name="OMG21Oct11"> {{Cite news|url = http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/10/ubuntu-12-04-lts-desktop-to-be-supported-for-five-years/|title = Ubuntu 12.04 LTS Desktop To Be Supported for Five Years|accessdate = 24 October 2011|last = Sneddon|first = Joey|authorlink = |year = 2011|month = October| work = [[OMG Ubuntu]]}}</ref>
Following the [[Ubuntu Developer Summit]] in early November 2011 Canonical announced that the default download for 12.04 will be 64-bit, with 32-bit still available as a user choice. Also the ISO size will increase to 750 MB, meaning that it will no longer fit on a CD, but will require a DVD. Other planned changes for this release include a much faster start up time for the [[Ubuntu Software Center]] and refinements to [[Unity (user interface)|Unity]]. This release will replace the [[Banshee (media player)|Banshee]] media player with [[Rhythmbox]] and drop the Tomboy note-taking application and the supporting [[Mono (software)|Mono]] framework as well.<ref name="WebUpd805Nov11"> {{Cite news|url = http://www.webupd8.org/2011/11/expected-changes-in-ubuntu-1204-precise.html|title = Expected Changes In Ubuntu 12.04 Precise Pangolin |accessdate = 8 November 2011|last = |first = Andrew|date = 15 November 2011| work = Web Upd8}}</ref><ref name="Sneddon04Nov11"> {{Cite news|url = http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/11/banshee-tomboy-and-mono-dropped-from-ubuntu-12-04-cd/|title = Banshee, Tomboy And Mono Dropped from Ubuntu 12.04 CD |accessdate = 8 November 2011|last = Sneddon |first = Joey|date = 4 November 2011| work = [[OMG Ubuntu]]}}</ref>

Each Ubuntu release follows the release of a new [[GNOME]] [[desktop environment]] version by a month.<ref name="ubuntuReleases" />
==Version timeline== {{Timeline Ubuntu Linux}}
==Version end of life== After each version of Ubuntu has reached its end-of-life time, its repositories are removed from the main Ubuntu servers and consequently the mirrors.<ref>{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-mirrors-announce/2007-May/000010.html |title=Old packages from unsupported Ubuntu releases will be removed from archive.ubuntu.com |last=Moffitt |first=Nick |mailinglist=ubuntu-mirrors-announce |date=31 May 2007 |accessdate=1 December 2008}}</ref> Older versions of Ubuntu repositories and releases can be found at [http://old-releases.ubuntu.com/releases/ old-releases.ubuntu.com].<ref name="oldrepos">{{cite web |url=http://releases.ubuntu.com/ |title=Ubuntu Releases |publisher=Ubuntu |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref>
